title: NAPTR Record Builder
description: Construct NAPTR (Naming Authority Pointer) records for dynamic delegation and service mapping

uFlag.label: U - Terminal rule (URI)
uFlag.description: The Rule is terminal and the result is a URI

sFlag.label: S - Terminal rule (SRV)
sFlag.description: The Rule is terminal and the result is for SRV lookup

aFlag.label: A - Terminal rule (Address)
aFlag.description: The Rule is terminal and the result is an address record

emptyFlag.label: Empty - Non-terminal
emptyFlag.description: The Rule is not terminal (continue processing)

input.domainTooltip: The domain name for this NAPTR record
input.domainDescription: The domain name for this NAPTR record
input.orderTooltip: Processing order - lower values are processed first (0-65535)
input.preferenceTooltip: Preference within the same order value (0-65535)
input.flagsTooltip: Control processing behavior - affects how the result is interpreted
input.serviceTooltip: Service identifier or protocol (e.g., E2U+sip for SIP services)
input.regexpTooltip: Regular expression for pattern matching and substitution (format: !pattern!replacement!)
input.replacementTooltip: Next domain to query, or '.' for terminal rules
input.replacementDescription: Domain name for next lookup, or "." for terminal rules

output.title: Generated NAPTR Record
output.placeholder: Fill in the required fields to generate the NAPTR record

warnings.title: Configuration Warnings
warnings.uriFlag: URI flag requires a valid substitution expression with delimiters
warnings.srvFlag: SRV flag typically requires a replacement domain, not "."
warnings.nonTerminal: Non-terminal rules should have a replacement domain for continued processing
warnings.regexpFormat: Regular expressions should follow the format: !pattern!replacement!
warnings.orderPreference: Order and Preference should typically be different values

info.aboutDescription: NAPTR (Naming Authority Pointer) records provide a way to map domain names to URIs or other domain names through regular expression-based rewriting. They're commonly used in telecommunications for ENUM (E.164 Number Mapping) and SIP services, allowing dynamic delegation and service discovery.
